title: Mitch Derangement Syndrome
summary: Pelosi gets the favorable press, yet McConnell always seems to outfox her.. Forget Iowa and New Hampshire. On the same day President Trump's legal team began its impeachment defense in the Senate, "Saturday Night Live" offered an insight into the Democratic mood: There's a new villain in town, and his name is Mitch McConnell.

title: A Stronger Germany Could Save Europe
summary: Angela Merkel's likely successor wants more defense spending and overseas deployments.. Hamburg

title: 'Black Wave' Review: Islam Against Itself
summary: Saudi Arabia, Iran and the 40-year rivalry that unraveled culture, religion and collective memory in the Middle East.. In the first line of "Black Wave," Kim Ghattas raises the question that haunts the Muslim realm: "What happened to us?" It recalls a famous line by Bernard Lewis, the great Middle East historian. There are two ways, he argued, in which cultures and nations deal with doom and decay. The first is to ask: "What did we do wrong?"-triggering self-scrutiny and self-help. The second: "Who did this to us?"

title: Welcome to the Party-Now Go Home
summary: Why I'm challenging longtime Democrat Jeff Van Drew in the Republican primary.. When I decided to run against Rep. Jeff Van Drew in New Jersey's Second District, he was one of the most vulnerable Democrats in the House. Republicans attacked him as a socialist who leaned too far left for a district that supported President Trump by nearly 5 points in 2016. So imagine my surprise when Mr. Van Drew reinvented himself as a Republican last month.

title: Genetics Will Revolutionize Social Science
summary: Knowledge of which DNA strand does what will make it easier to judge which policies are effective.. Almost all human traits are partly heritable. That's been known for decades. But until a few years ago, no one knew what specific bits of DNA code determine any given trait. Now, however, geneticists have identified at least a few hundred variants in the DNA code that are statistically associated with important traits such as intelligence, depression and risk tolerance. Over the next decade, they are on track to identify thousands of variants associated with dozens of traits. That achievement will open up the ability to score genetic potential on those traits and thereby revolutionize the social sciences.

title: Whirlpool Profits from Higher Prices
summary: Appliance maker said cost increases for some materials had cooled. Whirlpool Corp. said profit increased in the latest quarter after it raised prices on some appliances, and raw-material cost increases cooled.

title: Abolish Asia's 'Wet Markets,' Where Pandemics Breed
summary: Consumption of wild meat appears to be to blame for the Wuhan virus, as it was for SARS in 2003.. Chinese scientists have identified a "wet market"-where live and dead animals, including many wildlife species, are sold for consumption-as the chief suspect for the origin of the Wuhan coronavirus. The virus is closely related to the virus that caused the 2003 outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, which also was transmitted to humans from a wet market. China closed all markets that sell wildlife and temporarily banned the shipment and sale of wildlife throughout the country.

title: Arab Protesters Turn Away From the Tribe and Toward Nationalism
summary: A decade ago, 'the fight was against one man,' says one observer. 'Now it's against the entire system.'. The Egyptian diplomat Tahseen Bashir disdained Arab countries, notably excepting his own, as "tribes with flags." Bashir died in 2002, but his description is more apt than ever in a region scarred by raging sectarian feuds. Now a new cry against tribalism is increasingly heard in Lebanon, Iraq and beyond.

title: Rose Byrne on 24-Hour Flights With Her Toddlers
summary: The versatile Aussie actress on invisible sea creatures, trans-Pacific flights and why she hoards straw baskets from Asia. "I WAS LOOKING very serious indeed," recalled Rose Byrne of the moment she popped onto the American movie scene in 2002, standing-however briefly-beside Natalie Portman in "Star Wars: Episode II-Attack of the Clones." These days, the actress, 40, vacillates between comedic characters ("Bridesmaids" with Kristen Wiig, "Like a Boss" with Tiffany Haddish) and more dramatic roles like the one she's currently playing at Brooklyn Academy of Music (through March 8). In a modern rewrite of the Greek tragedy "Medea," Ms. Byrne, as the lead character, exacts lethal revenge on her straying husband, played, intriguingly, by her real-life fiancé Bobby Cannavale.

title: James Baker's War Powers Solution Is Out of Date
summary: The left side of the aisle has a different take on patriotism and national interest than the right side does, and that inhibits any consensual relationship on sharing of war powers.. In the political and cultural realm in which James A. Baker III served during his years in government, his proposal to "Repeal and Replace the War Powers Resolution" (op-ed, Jan. 21) would have made perfect sense. Today, the left side of the aisle has a different take on patriotism and national interest than the right side does, and that inhibits any consensual relationship on sharing of war powers.

title: Dr. Google Has Points Good and Less Good
summary: De-identified data linking diagnoses, medications, hospitalization and other outcomes can demonstrate the efficacy (or lack thereof) of programs and treatments.. The article "Google Will See You Now" (Exchange, Jan. 11) doesn't mention the extensive use of health insurance and other medical-system databases for research. De-identified data linking diagnoses, medications, hospitalization and other outcomes can demonstrate the efficacy (or lack thereof) of programs and treatments. I have used such data to consider different outcomes based on age, gender, duration of disease, number of previous medications used and other patient-specific information. We do need more information to improve our understanding of disease progress and treatment success. The current trend is toward asking patients to record information about symptoms and medical events on apps to move analyses closer to the overall impact on health-care utilization and quality of life. Rather than cast Google and health-system partners as villains, recognize they are advancing health care toward better management for subgroups of patients. These are all part of streamlining health care away from the fire-hose approach of giving everything to everyone, toward individualized, rational care. The net result will be lower costs and better outcomes.

title: Solve Exemption Problem By Ending Tariffs
summary: The best policy at this point isn't to grant exclusions but to get rid of these unnecessary and burdensome taxes.. Robert S. Wetherbee's "I Support Trump's Tariffs but Need an Exemption" (op-ed, Jan. 8) is a great example of why free-trade policy is the best approach when it comes to rent seeking. It's great that he saved 100 jobs directly in his plant, but how about the widespread job losses in energy, manufacturing and other sectors caused by the steel and aluminum tariffs? Some of these companies lost overseas customers permanently due to higher input costs.

title: Don't Bash Trump Trade Policy Without a Solution
summary: Reading Robert B. Zoellick's anti-tariff arguments, I kept waiting for his alternative solutions, which weren't forthcoming.. Reading Robert B. Zoellick's anti-tariff arguments, I kept waiting for his alternative solutions, which weren't forthcoming ("Trump's Pyrrhic Trade Victories," op-ed, Jan. 22). It appears Mr. Zoellick would have us continue on the pre-Trump path of allowing trading partners to steal American jobs and intellectual property unimpeded, thus continuing to lower our standard of living. Mr. Zoellick's arguments would have much more validity if our economy was cratering, which is the opposite of what's actually happening. The American worker is better off today than three years ago thanks to President Trump's strong leadership.

title: What Kobe Bryant Meant
summary: A tragedy in California takes the life of one of basketball's best modern players and eight others, including his daughter, Gianna. Kobe Bryant personified the modern sports alpha. On the court, he was the alpha, really-for better, and, sometimes, worse, in greatness and defeat, demanding to put the whole game on his shoulders when it mattered most, and even when it didn't matter much at all. He was not playing basketball to make friends. He kept a restless edge, even among his teammates. Bryant played to win, period, and over his 20 seasons as a Los Angeles Laker, he won all the time, finishing with five championship rings, and a firm space among the very best to ever play the game.

summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: At the Grammys, a New Guard in the Spotlight and a Nasty Fight Backstage
summary: As the Recording Academy and its suspended CEO trade accusations, the Grammys get ready for a star-studded night. The 62nd annual Grammy Awards on Sunday is bringing together star-studded performances by Billie Eilish, Lizzo and Aerosmith, wacky collaborations involving Lil Nas X and BTS and special tributes to artists like the late rapper Nipsey Hussle.

title: Virus Sparks Soul-Searching Over China's Wild Animal Trade
summary: Beijing faces uncomfortable questions over its failure to clean up wildlife trade and public calls for a permanent ban on wild meat. BEIJING-It didn't take long to identify the suspected source of a deadly coronavirus outbreak in the Chinese city of Wuhan: a cluster of vendors in a downtown market offering carcasses and live specimens of dozens of wild animals-from bamboo rats to ostriches, baby crocodiles and hedgehogs.

title: The Bryant Who Dreamed of Playing in the WNBA
summary: Kobe Bryant often said his daughter Gianna, who was 13 years old, rekindled his love for the game. She was a 13-year-old who harbored dreams of playing in the Women's National Basketball Association. She was a guard with an uncanny ability to create open shots. And she happened to have one of the greatest basketball teachers on the planet living in her house.

title: Nathan Chen Jumps to Another U.S. Figure Skating Title
summary: The 20-year-old is progressing methodically with a plan to soar at the 2022 Beijing Games, after disappointment at the 2018 Olympics. GREENSBORO, N.C.-In the past two seasons, Nathan Chen took home a gold medal from every event he entered: two U.S. national championships, four Grand Prix events, two Grand Prix finals, two world championships...with one exception.

title: China Urges Calm Over Virus During 'Critical Period'
summary: Wuhan mayor expects another roughly 1,000 confirmed coronavirus infection cases; Hong Kong to deny entry to people who have visited Hubei during the past two weeks. BEIJING-Chinese public-health officials urged calm on Sunday even as they warned that the dangerous new virus at the heart of a fast-spreading outbreak is growing more contagious, piling more pressure on an already strained containment effort.

title: Republican Weld Makes Little Traction in New York in Run Against Trump
summary: Top GOP official in the state doubts the former Massachusetts governor will make the April 28 primary ballot. Former Massachusetts Gov. William Weld says his Republican primary challenge to President Trump is a moral question for the party, but the top GOP official in New York doubts he'll even make the April 28 primary ballot.
